text: The Lord said, I will bring again from Bashan, I will bring my people again from the depths of the sea:
text_kjv: The Lord said, I will bring again from Bashan, I will bring my people again from the depths of the sea:
text_niv: The Lord says, “I will bring them from Bashan;I will bring them from the depths of the sea,
text_esv: The Lord said, “I will bring them back from Bashan, I will bring them back from the depths of the sea,
text_nlt: The Lord says, “I will bring my enemies down from Bashan;I will bring them up from the depths of the sea.
text_msg: saying, "I tied up the Dragon in knots,put a muzzle on the Deep Blue Sea."
text_nasb: The Lord said, 'I will bring [them] back from Bashan. I will bring [them] back from the depths of the sea;
context: Psalm 68 is a complex and triumphant hymn celebrating God's power and deliverance of his people. Understanding verse 22 requires grasping the historical and geographical significance of Bashan and the sea. Bashan, located northeast of the Sea of Galilee, was known for its fertile land, strong cattle, and rugged mountains. It was a region often associated with strength and power, and it represented a seemingly unreachable, perhaps even hostile, territory. Conquering Bashan signified complete victory. The 'depths of the sea' likely alludes to the Red Sea crossing during the Exodus, where God miraculously delivered the Israelites from Egyptian slavery. The sea, in ancient Near Eastern literature, often symbolizes chaos and uncontrollable forces. The mention of both Bashan and the sea emphasizes the completeness of God's deliverance, covering all terrains and circumstances, from the high mountains to the deepest waters. It also resonates with themes of conquest and re-establishment. David, traditionally attributed as the author of the Psalm, likely wrote it to commemorate God's faithfulness in battles and to inspire confidence in future challenges. The historical context of Israel's struggles and God's interventions shaped the understanding of God as a warrior-king who secures his people's safety and prosperity. The imagery of retrieving his people from these disparate and dangerous places illustrates the encompassing nature of his redemptive power.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 68:22 speaks to the boundless extent of God's power and his unwavering commitment to his covenant people. 'I will bring again from Bashan' signifies that no place, no matter how remote or fortified, is beyond God's reach. It highlights his ability to overcome the strongest opposition and recover what has been lost. Bashan, representing a place of strength and possibly even exile, symbolizes circumstances where people feel trapped or overwhelmed. God's promise to bring his people from there assures them that he can rescue them from even the most challenging situations. Similarly, 'I will bring my people again from the depths of the sea' echoes the Exodus narrative and God's ability to deliver his people from seemingly insurmountable odds. The sea, as a symbol of chaos and death, represents the overwhelming forces that threaten to destroy God's people, whether physical enemies or spiritual forces. God's triumph over the sea demonstrates his power over these forces and his ability to bring life and hope from the depths of despair. This verse also points to the theme of restoration and redemption. God is not merely rescuing his people; he is bringing them 'again,' suggesting a return to a place of blessing and favor. It conveys a message of hope and assurance that God's redemptive work is comprehensive and that he will ultimately restore his people to their rightful inheritance. The verse underscores God's sovereignty, faithfulness, and the all-encompassing nature of his redemptive work.
application: Psalm 68:22 offers profound encouragement and practical guidance for modern believers facing various challenges. When confronted with seemingly insurmountable obstacles, such as health issues, financial struggles, or broken relationships, we can draw strength from God's promise to 'bring again from Bashan.' This means that no situation is too difficult for God to handle. We should not be discouraged by the apparent strength of our adversaries or the depth of our problems. Instead, we should trust in God's power to overcome these obstacles and bring us back to a place of wholeness and well-being. Similarly, the promise to 'bring my people again from the depths of the sea' assures us that God can rescue us from the most hopeless situations. When we feel overwhelmed by despair, guilt, or addiction, we can cling to the hope that God can deliver us from these 'depths' and bring us into a new life of freedom and purpose. This verse encourages us to actively seek God's intervention in our lives and to trust in his ability to work miracles. It calls us to remember the Exodus and other instances where God demonstrated his power to deliver his people from impossible situations. Moreover, Psalm 68:22 inspires us to extend God's love and compassion to others who are struggling. Just as God brought his people from Bashan and the sea, we are called to reach out to those who are trapped in difficult circumstances and offer them hope and support. This could involve providing practical assistance, offering encouragement, or sharing the Gospel message of salvation. The verse also serves as a reminder that God's redemptive work is ongoing. He is constantly working to bring his people back to himself and to restore them to their full potential. We should cooperate with his work by living lives that are pleasing to him and by participating in his mission to reconcile the world to himself.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your powerful promise in Psalm 68:22. We praise you for your unwavering commitment to your people and for your ability to overcome any obstacle. Lord, we confess that we often feel overwhelmed by the challenges in our lives. We face our own 'Bashans' of difficulty and our own 'seas' of despair. We ask for your strength and guidance to navigate these challenges with faith and courage. Remind us of your past faithfulness and your power to deliver us from even the most hopeless situations. Help us to trust in your promises and to seek your intervention in our lives. Use us as instruments of your love and compassion to reach out to those who are struggling and to offer them hope and support. May we always remember that you are the God who brings us again from Bashan and from the depths of the sea. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Bashan, a region known for its fertile land and strong cattle, symbolized strength and a seemingly unreachable territory. God bringing his people from Bashan highlights his ability to overcome any obstacle, no matter how formidable, and rescue his people from even the strongest opposition.
faqs.question: Q1: What is the significance of Bashan in Psalm 68:22?

faqs.answer: The 'depths of the sea' symbolize chaos, overwhelming forces, and seemingly insurmountable obstacles. It alludes to the Red Sea crossing and represents situations where people feel hopeless or trapped. God's power over the sea shows his ability to deliver from the depths of despair.
faqs.question: Q2: What does the 'depths of the sea' represent in the verse?

faqs.answer: The phrase 'depths of the sea' directly echoes the Exodus narrative, where God miraculously delivered the Israelites from Egyptian slavery. It reinforces the idea that God has the power to deliver his people from even the most desperate situations, mirroring the Exodus event.
faqs.question: Q3: How does Psalm 68:22 relate to the Exodus story?

faqs.answer: 'I will bring again' suggests restoration and redemption. It's not just about rescue, but a return to a place of blessing and favor. It conveys that God's redemptive work is comprehensive, aiming to fully restore his people to their rightful inheritance and relationship with Him.
faqs.question: Q4: What does 'I will bring again' signify in this verse?

faqs.answer: We can apply this verse by trusting God's power to overcome any obstacle in our lives, whether financial, relational, or spiritual. It assures us that God can deliver us from despair and restore us to wholeness, calling us to seek His intervention in every difficulty.
